issue.title: [Suggestion] Development brach
issue.body:
BlueSky is in need of a development branch, with the master branch being updated only periodically after all the changes have been tested and accepted. 

The changes that are tested can then be merged into the main branch.

issue.title: [Suggestion] Development brach
issue.body:
BlueSky is in need of a development branch, with the master branch being updated only periodically after all the changes have been tested and accepted. 

The changes that are tested can then be merged into the main branch.

comment.body:
Yes, but with a slight difference. Instead of a general "development branch", it is better to use a system like releases. This addresses the same issue. 

Explanation: 
In practice most of the times you want the latest version, because of some bug fix or modification. So calling it development branch is strange as it will be the most often used. But if you need a thoroughly tested, stable version that is not changed during your experiment, you can take a (initially the latest) release and stick to it

An added benefit is that by having the previous releases available  you can keep using an older release for compatibility or if you're not interested in new features.

issue.title: [Bug] Autopilot uses the incorrect value to calculate when to slow down for a turn
issue.body:
In Autopilot.py, on line 381, the distance at which an aircraft needs to start slowing down in order to turn is calculated. However, it is currently calculated using the maximum velocity of the aircraft:

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.perf.vmax, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

If the aircraft is not travelling close to its performance-based maximum velocity, then it starts slowing down too early. I think the calculation should use the actual speed of the aircraft.

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.tas, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

issue.title: [Bug] Autopilot uses the incorrect value to calculate when to slow down for a turn
issue.body:
In Autopilot.py, on line 381, the distance at which an aircraft needs to start slowing down in order to turn is calculated. However, it is currently calculated using the maximum velocity of the aircraft:

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.perf.vmax, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

If the aircraft is not travelling close to its performance-based maximum velocity, then it starts slowing down too early. I think the calculation should use the actual speed of the aircraft.

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.tas, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

commits.message: - change vmax to actual speed fpor calculation dx to turnspd

SWTOC/SWTOD: Extension of autopilot logic for vertical path following (VNAV)

Switch on or off the:
 - top of descent logic (descend as early as allowed by altitude constraints in flight plan and as fast as allowed by performance)
 - top of climb logic (climb as early as allowed by altitude contraints in flight plan ans as fast as allowed by performance)

 As this logic is normally used by the FMS of an ailiner it is on by default, but can be switched  on or off with the SWTOC and SWTOD command:

     acid SWTOC ON/OFF
     acid SWTOD ON/OFF

 When swithced off, the aircraft will start climbing or descending to the next altitude contstraint with a vertical speed aiming to arrive at the next altitude contraint further down the flight plan. (Intermediate waypoints without altitude contraints are irrelevant and not considered in the VNAV logic for altitude.)

 Also some cleaning up: more comments have been added top the source code and old code has been deleted.
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Syntax check by AT command adapted to cope with command without argument types

- VNAV descent mode now accounts for turndist in case of small altitude changes and large course deviations to make VNAV more robust for small vehicles.

And comments etc.

issue.title: ALT Command
issue.body:
Hi all,

I'm trying to implement a simulator that takes action commands to control a plane at each timestep. So far, I have been creating aircraft using "CRE", and simulating them in 2d using "MOVE" and changing the "hdg" and "spd" fields based on some action input that increments these values. I'd like to extend this environment to the 3d case and control altitude at each timestep in a similar way. 

I've tried using "ALT" and specifying "alt" and "vspd", but I get a strange behavior when doing so. For example, if I specify only positive "vspd", and set "alt" to equal current altitude + ("vspd"/60)xDT where DT is the timestep increment in seconds the plane will only descend until it hits the ground. Am I misinterpreting the "ALT" or "MOVE" commands? Do I need to instantiate VNAV or some form of autopilot before being able to control altitude? Is there an area of the codebase where vertical climb dynamics are processed that I should take a look at?

Any help is greatly appreciated! Thank you for your work on this great tool -

comment.body:
No, that does not sound good. Can you given me the exact scenario file or commands you use? Then I can see what is going on.

I see ok - thanks for the quick answer. I have been using a different target altitude than the current altitude, with a positive climb rate. Should this still be producing a rapid altitude loss? The plane speed is set to a reasonably high value.

Thanks for your help -

issue.title: Climb profiles for newly generated aircraft
issue.body:
Is there a reason that newly generated aircraft will always take a more extreme climb to reach the first waypoint when compared to existing aircraft on the same route?

In the image AC1 is following a route of 2 waypoints. 25 seconds after reaching the first waypoint AC2 is added with the same parameters as AC1 and the same next waypoint. AC2 takes an aggressive climb reaches the next wpt alt 2 minutes before arriving while AC1 climbs for the entire distance.

![ac alt issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29206618/193643087-d1276adf-d519-4057-a6ac-347a70f534bf.png)

Here is the MRC for testing that I used:
```python
import bluesky as bs
from bluesky.simulation import ScreenIO
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

from tqdm import trange


class ScreenDummy(ScreenIO):
    """
    Dummy class for the screen. Inherits from ScreenIO to make sure all the
    necessary methods are there. This class is there to reimplement the echo
    method so that console messages are printed.
    """

    def __init__(self, verbose=False):
        """Initilising the dummy screen

        Args:
            verbose (bool, optional): If BlueSky messages should be displayed. Defaults to False.
        """

        super().__init__()
        self.verbose = verbose

    def echo(self, text="", flags=0):
        """Just print echo messages"""

        if self.verbose:
            print("BlueSky console:", text)


route = [[52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50], [52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60]]

start = [52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15]

bs.init(mode="sim", detached=True)
bs.scr = ScreenDummy()

ac = {}

bs.traf.cre(
    acid="AC1",
    actype="AMZN",
    aclat=start[0],
    aclon=start[1],
    achdg=start[3],
    acalt=start[2],
    acspd=start[4],
)


for wpt in route:
    bs.stack.stack(f"ADDWPT AC1 {wpt[0]} {wpt[1]} {wpt[2]}")
bs.stack.stack("LNAV AC1 ON; VNAV AC1 ON")

bs.stack.stack("DT 1; FF")

c = 0

for i in trange(700):
    bs.sim.step()

    for i in range(bs.traf.ntraf):
        if bs.traf.id[i] not in ac:
            ac[bs.traf.id[i]] = [
                [
                    bs.sim.simt,
                    bs.traf.lat[i],
                    bs.traf.lon[i],
                    bs.traf.alt[i],
                    bs.traf.hdg[i],
                    bs.traf.tas[i],
                ]
            ]

        else:
            ac[bs.traf.id[i]].append(
                [
                    bs.sim.simt,
                    bs.traf.lat[i],
                    bs.traf.lon[i],
                    bs.traf.alt[i],
                    bs.traf.hdg[i],
                    bs.traf.tas[i],
                ]
            )

    if bs.traf.ap.route[0].iactwp == 1:
        c += 1

    if c == 25:
        bs.traf.cre(
            acid="AC2",
            actype="AMZN",
            aclat=bs.traf.lat[0],
            aclon=bs.traf.lon[0],
            achdg=bs.traf.hdg[0],
            acalt=bs.traf.alt[0],
            acspd=bs.traf.tas[0],
        )

        wpt = route[1]
        bs.stack.stack(f"ADDWPT AC2 {wpt[0]} {wpt[1]} {wpt[2]}")
        bs.stack.stack("LNAV AC2 ON; VNAV AC2 ON")


print(ac.keys())

plt.plot(np.array(ac["AC1"])[:, 0], np.array(ac["AC1"])[:, 3], label="AC1")
plt.plot(np.array(ac["AC2"])[:, 0], np.array(ac["AC2"])[:, 3], label="AC2")

plt.legend()

plt.show()
```

comment.body:
Dear Ellis,

There are two things at play: timing, setting a (too) large time step and a safety net of the autopilot. 

First of all, when I run the same scenario, but with smaller DT than the 1 second that you use, I get no difference between the two aircraft:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7159044/194102256-66c2ea56-8090-4117-aaaa-e08300248b3e.png)

What is happening is that you use a DT=1 sec, which is quite coarse when it comes to waypoint passing. The jump you see in V/S is a reaction to passing a waypoint and not making the altitude with the calculated V/S and therefore going to this altitude with the maximum V/S while turning to the next leg.

I suspect the difference occurs, because the waypoint switching does not happen at t=rounded to a second, but something later and it misses the waypoint switching and there switches later, resulting in emergency climb.

Could you try it with a smaller DT, say DT=0.1? Then we can see whether it disappears.

By the way, I used the following scenario file to test it, first used the AT HOLD command to find the time of the first WP passing, this was around 10:04, so I add the 2nd aircraft at 10:29. Also check out the (yet) undocumented PLOT command!

00:00:00.00>CRE AC1,AMZN,52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15
00:00:00.00>PAN AC1;++++;pos ac1
00:00:00.00>ADDWPT AC1 52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50
00:00:00.00>ADDWPT AC1 52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60
# 00:00:00.00>AC1 AT AC1001 DO HOLD
00:00:00.00>PLOT sim.simt, traf.alt,1
00:00:00.00>LNAV AC1 ON; VNAV AC1 ON
00:10:29.00>CRE AC2,AMZN,52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15
00:10:29.00>ADDWPT AC2 52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50
00:10:29.00>ADDWPT AC2 52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60
00:10:29.00>LNAV AC2 ON; VNAV AC2 ON

Best regards,
     Jacco Hoekstra

comment.body:
Thanks, we will check what happens in this specific case of using the current altitude as selected altitude. It should go to ALT HOLD.

In general: Vertical speed only works with an altitude command for a different altitude than the current altitude. It is an extra specification of the ALT command. This also means you can not use the V/S without a target altitude.

Does this answer help already?

Best regards,
    Jacco Hoekstra

issue.title: [Bug] Autopilot uses the incorrect value to calculate when to slow down for a turn
issue.body:
In Autopilot.py, on line 381, the distance at which an aircraft needs to start slowing down in order to turn is calculated. However, it is currently calculated using the maximum velocity of the aircraft:

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.perf.vmax, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

If the aircraft is not travelling close to its performance-based maximum velocity, then it starts slowing down too early. I think the calculation should use the actual speed of the aircraft.

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.tas, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

issue.title: [Bug] Autopilot uses the incorrect value to calculate when to slow down for a turn
issue.body:
In Autopilot.py, on line 381, the distance at which an aircraft needs to start slowing down in order to turn is calculated. However, it is currently calculated using the maximum velocity of the aircraft:

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.perf.vmax, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

If the aircraft is not travelling close to its performance-based maximum velocity, then it starts slowing down too early. I think the calculation should use the actual speed of the aircraft.

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.tas, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

commits.message: - change vmax to actual speed fpor calculation dx to turnspd

SWTOC/SWTOD: Extension of autopilot logic for vertical path following (VNAV)

Switch on or off the:
 - top of descent logic (descend as early as allowed by altitude constraints in flight plan and as fast as allowed by performance)
 - top of climb logic (climb as early as allowed by altitude contraints in flight plan ans as fast as allowed by performance)

 As this logic is normally used by the FMS of an ailiner it is on by default, but can be switched  on or off with the SWTOC and SWTOD command:

     acid SWTOC ON/OFF
     acid SWTOD ON/OFF

 When swithced off, the aircraft will start climbing or descending to the next altitude contstraint with a vertical speed aiming to arrive at the next altitude contraint further down the flight plan. (Intermediate waypoints without altitude contraints are irrelevant and not considered in the VNAV logic for altitude.)

 Also some cleaning up: more comments have been added top the source code and old code has been deleted.
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Syntax check by AT command adapted to cope with command without argument types

- VNAV descent mode now accounts for turndist in case of small altitude changes and large course deviations to make VNAV more robust for small vehicles.

And comments etc.

issue.title: ALT Command
issue.body:
Hi all,

I'm trying to implement a simulator that takes action commands to control a plane at each timestep. So far, I have been creating aircraft using "CRE", and simulating them in 2d using "MOVE" and changing the "hdg" and "spd" fields based on some action input that increments these values. I'd like to extend this environment to the 3d case and control altitude at each timestep in a similar way. 

I've tried using "ALT" and specifying "alt" and "vspd", but I get a strange behavior when doing so. For example, if I specify only positive "vspd", and set "alt" to equal current altitude + ("vspd"/60)xDT where DT is the timestep increment in seconds the plane will only descend until it hits the ground. Am I misinterpreting the "ALT" or "MOVE" commands? Do I need to instantiate VNAV or some form of autopilot before being able to control altitude? Is there an area of the codebase where vertical climb dynamics are processed that I should take a look at?

Any help is greatly appreciated! Thank you for your work on this great tool -

issue.title: Climb profiles for newly generated aircraft
issue.body:
Is there a reason that newly generated aircraft will always take a more extreme climb to reach the first waypoint when compared to existing aircraft on the same route?

In the image AC1 is following a route of 2 waypoints. 25 seconds after reaching the first waypoint AC2 is added with the same parameters as AC1 and the same next waypoint. AC2 takes an aggressive climb reaches the next wpt alt 2 minutes before arriving while AC1 climbs for the entire distance.

![ac alt issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29206618/193643087-d1276adf-d519-4057-a6ac-347a70f534bf.png)

Here is the MRC for testing that I used:
```python
import bluesky as bs
from bluesky.simulation import ScreenIO
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

from tqdm import trange


class ScreenDummy(ScreenIO):
    """
    Dummy class for the screen. Inherits from ScreenIO to make sure all the
    necessary methods are there. This class is there to reimplement the echo
    method so that console messages are printed.
    """

    def __init__(self, verbose=False):
        """Initilising the dummy screen

        Args:
            verbose (bool, optional): If BlueSky messages should be displayed. Defaults to False.
        """

        super().__init__()
        self.verbose = verbose

    def echo(self, text="", flags=0):
        """Just print echo messages"""

        if self.verbose:
            print("BlueSky console:", text)


route = [[52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50], [52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60]]

start = [52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15]

bs.init(mode="sim", detached=True)
bs.scr = ScreenDummy()

ac = {}

bs.traf.cre(
    acid="AC1",
    actype="AMZN",
    aclat=start[0],
    aclon=start[1],
    achdg=start[3],
    acalt=start[2],
    acspd=start[4],
)


for wpt in route:
    bs.stack.stack(f"ADDWPT AC1 {wpt[0]} {wpt[1]} {wpt[2]}")
bs.stack.stack("LNAV AC1 ON; VNAV AC1 ON")

bs.stack.stack("DT 1; FF")

c = 0

for i in trange(700):
    bs.sim.step()

    for i in range(bs.traf.ntraf):
        if bs.traf.id[i] not in ac:
            ac[bs.traf.id[i]] = [
                [
                    bs.sim.simt,
                    bs.traf.lat[i],
                    bs.traf.lon[i],
                    bs.traf.alt[i],
                    bs.traf.hdg[i],
                    bs.traf.tas[i],
                ]
            ]

        else:
            ac[bs.traf.id[i]].append(
                [
                    bs.sim.simt,
                    bs.traf.lat[i],
                    bs.traf.lon[i],
                    bs.traf.alt[i],
                    bs.traf.hdg[i],
                    bs.traf.tas[i],
                ]
            )

    if bs.traf.ap.route[0].iactwp == 1:
        c += 1

    if c == 25:
        bs.traf.cre(
            acid="AC2",
            actype="AMZN",
            aclat=bs.traf.lat[0],
            aclon=bs.traf.lon[0],
            achdg=bs.traf.hdg[0],
            acalt=bs.traf.alt[0],
            acspd=bs.traf.tas[0],
        )

        wpt = route[1]
        bs.stack.stack(f"ADDWPT AC2 {wpt[0]} {wpt[1]} {wpt[2]}")
        bs.stack.stack("LNAV AC2 ON; VNAV AC2 ON")


print(ac.keys())

plt.plot(np.array(ac["AC1"])[:, 0], np.array(ac["AC1"])[:, 3], label="AC1")
plt.plot(np.array(ac["AC2"])[:, 0], np.array(ac["AC2"])[:, 3], label="AC2")

plt.legend()

plt.show()
```

comment.body:
Dear Ellis,

There are two things at play: timing, setting a (too) large time step and a safety net of the autopilot. 

First of all, when I run the same scenario, but with smaller DT than the 1 second that you use, I get no difference between the two aircraft:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7159044/194102256-66c2ea56-8090-4117-aaaa-e08300248b3e.png)

What is happening is that you use a DT=1 sec, which is quite coarse when it comes to waypoint passing. The jump you see in V/S is a reaction to passing a waypoint and not making the altitude with the calculated V/S and therefore going to this altitude with the maximum V/S while turning to the next leg.

I suspect the difference occurs, because the waypoint switching does not happen at t=rounded to a second, but something later and it misses the waypoint switching and there switches later, resulting in emergency climb.

Could you try it with a smaller DT, say DT=0.1? Then we can see whether it disappears.

By the way, I used the following scenario file to test it, first used the AT HOLD command to find the time of the first WP passing, this was around 10:04, so I add the 2nd aircraft at 10:29. Also check out the (yet) undocumented PLOT command!

00:00:00.00>CRE AC1,AMZN,52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15
00:00:00.00>PAN AC1;++++;pos ac1
00:00:00.00>ADDWPT AC1 52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50
00:00:00.00>ADDWPT AC1 52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60
# 00:00:00.00>AC1 AT AC1001 DO HOLD
00:00:00.00>PLOT sim.simt, traf.alt,1
00:00:00.00>LNAV AC1 ON; VNAV AC1 ON
00:10:29.00>CRE AC2,AMZN,52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15
00:10:29.00>ADDWPT AC2 52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50
00:10:29.00>ADDWPT AC2 52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60
00:10:29.00>LNAV AC2 ON; VNAV AC2 ON

Best regards,
     Jacco Hoekstra

comment.body:
Thanks, we will check what happens in this specific case of using the current altitude as selected altitude. It should go to ALT HOLD.

In general: Vertical speed only works with an altitude command for a different altitude than the current altitude. It is an extra specification of the ALT command. This also means you can not use the V/S without a target altitude.

Does this answer help already?

Best regards,
    Jacco Hoekstra

issue.title: [Suggestion] Development brach
issue.body:
BlueSky is in need of a development branch, with the master branch being updated only periodically after all the changes have been tested and accepted. 

The changes that are tested can then be merged into the main branch.

issue.title: [Suggestion] Development brach
issue.body:
BlueSky is in need of a development branch, with the master branch being updated only periodically after all the changes have been tested and accepted. 

The changes that are tested can then be merged into the main branch.

comment.body:
Yes, but with a slight difference. Instead of a general "development branch", it is better to use a system like releases. This addresses the same issue. 

Explanation: 
In practice most of the times you want the latest version, because of some bug fix or modification. So calling it development branch is strange as it will be the most often used. But if you need a thoroughly tested, stable version that is not changed during your experiment, you can take a (initially the latest) release and stick to it

An added benefit is that by having the previous releases available  you can keep using an older release for compatibility or if you're not interested in new features.

issue.title: [Bug] Autopilot uses the incorrect value to calculate when to slow down for a turn
issue.body:
In Autopilot.py, on line 381, the distance at which an aircraft needs to start slowing down in order to turn is calculated. However, it is currently calculated using the maximum velocity of the aircraft:

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.perf.vmax, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

If the aircraft is not travelling close to its performance-based maximum velocity, then it starts slowing down too early. I think the calculation should use the actual speed of the aircraft.

```python
dxturnspdchg = distaccel(turntas,bs.traf.tas, bs.traf.perf.axmax)
```

If the aircraft is not travelling close to its performance-based maximum velocity, then it starts slowing down too early. I think the calculation should use the actual speed of the aircraft.

commits.message: - change vmax to actual speed fpor calculation dx to turnspd

SWTOC/SWTOD: Extension of autopilot logic for vertical path following (VNAV)

Switch on or off the:
 - top of descent logic (descend as early as allowed by altitude constraints in flight plan and as fast as allowed by performance)
 - top of climb logic (climb as early as allowed by altitude contraints in flight plan ans as fast as allowed by performance)

 As this logic is normally used by the FMS of an ailiner it is on by default, but can be switched  on or off with the SWTOC and SWTOD command:

     acid SWTOC ON/OFF
     acid SWTOD ON/OFF

 When swithced off, the aircraft will start climbing or descending to the next altitude contstraint with a vertical speed aiming to arrive at the next altitude contraint further down the flight plan. (Intermediate waypoints without altitude contraints are irrelevant and not considered in the VNAV logic for altitude.)

 Also some cleaning up: more comments have been added top the source code and old code has been deleted.
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'
Syntax check by AT command adapted to cope with command without argument types

- VNAV descent mode now accounts for turndist in case of small altitude changes and large course deviations to make VNAV more robust for small vehicles.

And comments etc.

issue.title: ALT Command
issue.body:
Hi all,

I'm trying to implement a simulator that takes action commands to control a plane at each timestep. So far, I have been creating aircraft using "CRE", and simulating them in 2d using "MOVE" and changing the "hdg" and "spd" fields based on some action input that increments these values. I'd like to extend this environment to the 3d case and control altitude at each timestep in a similar way. 

I've tried using "ALT" and specifying "alt" and "vspd", but I get a strange behavior when doing so. For example, if I specify only positive "vspd", and set "alt" to equal current altitude + ("vspd"/60)xDT where DT is the timestep increment in seconds the plane will only descend until it hits the ground. Am I misinterpreting the "ALT" or "MOVE" commands? Do I need to instantiate VNAV or some form of autopilot before being able to control altitude? Is there an area of the codebase where vertical climb dynamics are processed that I should take a look at?

Any help is greatly appreciated! Thank you for your work on this great tool -

issue.title: Climb profiles for newly generated aircraft
issue.body:
Is there a reason that newly generated aircraft will always take a more extreme climb to reach the first waypoint when compared to existing aircraft on the same route?

In the image AC1 is following a route of 2 waypoints. 25 seconds after reaching the first waypoint AC2 is added with the same parameters as AC1 and the same next waypoint. AC2 takes an aggressive climb reaches the next wpt alt 2 minutes before arriving while AC1 climbs for the entire distance.

![ac alt issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29206618/193643087-d1276adf-d519-4057-a6ac-347a70f534bf.png)

Here is the MRC for testing that I used:
```python
import bluesky as bs
from bluesky.simulation import ScreenIO
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

from tqdm import trange


class ScreenDummy(ScreenIO):
    """
    Dummy class for the screen. Inherits from ScreenIO to make sure all the
    necessary methods are there. This class is there to reimplement the echo
    method so that console messages are printed.
    """

    def __init__(self, verbose=False):
        """Initilising the dummy screen

        Args:
            verbose (bool, optional): If BlueSky messages should be displayed. Defaults to False.
        """

        super().__init__()
        self.verbose = verbose

    def echo(self, text="", flags=0):
        """Just print echo messages"""

        if self.verbose:
            print("BlueSky console:", text)


route = [[52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50], [52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60]]

start = [52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15]

bs.init(mode="sim", detached=True)
bs.scr = ScreenDummy()

ac = {}

bs.traf.cre(
    acid="AC1",
    actype="AMZN",
    aclat=start[0],
    aclon=start[1],
    achdg=start[3],
    acalt=start[2],
    acspd=start[4],
)


for wpt in route:
    bs.stack.stack(f"ADDWPT AC1 {wpt[0]} {wpt[1]} {wpt[2]}")
bs.stack.stack("LNAV AC1 ON; VNAV AC1 ON")

bs.stack.stack("DT 1; FF")

c = 0

for i in trange(700):
    bs.sim.step()

    for i in range(bs.traf.ntraf):
        if bs.traf.id[i] not in ac:
            ac[bs.traf.id[i]] = [
                [
                    bs.sim.simt,
                    bs.traf.lat[i],
                    bs.traf.lon[i],
                    bs.traf.alt[i],
                    bs.traf.hdg[i],
                    bs.traf.tas[i],
                ]
            ]

        else:
            ac[bs.traf.id[i]].append(
                [
                    bs.sim.simt,
                    bs.traf.lat[i],
                    bs.traf.lon[i],
                    bs.traf.alt[i],
                    bs.traf.hdg[i],
                    bs.traf.tas[i],
                ]
            )

    if bs.traf.ap.route[0].iactwp == 1:
        c += 1

    if c == 25:
        bs.traf.cre(
            acid="AC2",
            actype="AMZN",
            aclat=bs.traf.lat[0],
            aclon=bs.traf.lon[0],
            achdg=bs.traf.hdg[0],
            acalt=bs.traf.alt[0],
            acspd=bs.traf.tas[0],
        )

        wpt = route[1]
        bs.stack.stack(f"ADDWPT AC2 {wpt[0]} {wpt[1]} {wpt[2]}")
        bs.stack.stack("LNAV AC2 ON; VNAV AC2 ON")


print(ac.keys())

plt.plot(np.array(ac["AC1"])[:, 0], np.array(ac["AC1"])[:, 3], label="AC1")
plt.plot(np.array(ac["AC2"])[:, 0], np.array(ac["AC2"])[:, 3], label="AC2")

plt.legend()

plt.show()
```

comment.body:
Dear Ellis,

There are two things at play: timing, setting a (too) large time step and a safety net of the autopilot. 

First of all, when I run the same scenario, but with smaller DT than the 1 second that you use, I get no difference between the two aircraft:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7159044/194102256-66c2ea56-8090-4117-aaaa-e08300248b3e.png)

What is happening is that you use a DT=1 sec, which is quite coarse when it comes to waypoint passing. The jump you see in V/S is a reaction to passing a waypoint and not making the altitude with the calculated V/S and therefore going to this altitude with the maximum V/S while turning to the next leg.

I suspect the difference occurs, because the waypoint switching does not happen at t=rounded to a second, but something later and it misses the waypoint switching and there switches later, resulting in emergency climb.

Could you try it with a smaller DT, say DT=0.1? Then we can see whether it disappears.

By the way, I used the following scenario file to test it, first used the AT HOLD command to find the time of the first WP passing, this was around 10:04, so I add the 2nd aircraft at 10:29. Also check out the (yet) undocumented PLOT command!

00:00:00.00>CRE AC1,AMZN,52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15
00:00:00.00>PAN AC1;++++;pos ac1
00:00:00.00>ADDWPT AC1 52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50
00:00:00.00>ADDWPT AC1 52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60
# 00:00:00.00>AC1 AT AC1001 DO HOLD
00:00:00.00>PLOT sim.simt, traf.alt,1
00:00:00.00>LNAV AC1 ON; VNAV AC1 ON
00:10:29.00>CRE AC2,AMZN,52.07, -0.619361, 10, 20, 15
00:10:29.00>ADDWPT AC2 52.093472, -0.560397, 1000, 50
00:10:29.00>ADDWPT AC2 52.067749, -0.545041, 1750, 60
00:10:29.00>LNAV AC2 ON; VNAV AC2 ON

Best regards,
     Jacco Hoekstra

comment.body:
Thanks, we will check what happens in this specific case of using the current altitude as selected altitude. It should go to ALT HOLD.

In general: Vertical speed only works with an altitude command for a different altitude than the current altitude. It is an extra specification of the ALT command. This also means you can not use the V/S without a target altitude.

Does this answer help already?

Best regards,
    Jacco Hoekstra
